Expectation1: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation1: Thunderstorm cells force multiple flights to reroute, increasing handoffs between sectors.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: The radar screen glowed with a tangle of blips, each one a plane seeking safe passage through the storm. My headset crackled with voices—colleagues coordinating, pilots requesting new headings, the tension in the room thick as the thunder outside. I knew every decision mattered, every handoff had to be flawless. The storm had forced half the flights in my sector to reroute, and the workload was relentless. I glanced at the clock. Sunday service would start in twenty minutes. My church expected me there, not just to worship, but to help with the youth group and greet newcomers. I’d promised myself and my community to be present, to live my faith not just in words but in action. But now, the skies demanded my full attention. Planes depended on me, and so did my church. My heart pounded as I weighed the needs of the pilots above and the congregation below, torn between the safety of hundreds and the commitments of my faith.
